entry.title: Fringe - Season 1 - Episode 1 - Pilot
entry.content:
Fringe - Season 1 - Episode 1 - Pilot20130415
I've been hearing about this show for a while and now that it is
over, I can watch it. I thought the first episode was fun. I
liked the actors and the action was interesting. I think the two
scientists characters will have to grow on me a little, because I
think they act a little too extreme-to-type. The world it seems
to be creating is neat.

I found a lot of the minor details of the plot to be
obvious---for example, you can't have a guy tell a girl he loves
her (and have her be happy about it) on the first episode, unless
you're going to kill him or cause him to be a bad guy: and they
did both!

I think my only complaint about it is the way "fringe science" is
used as some weird boogey-man discussed in hushed tones, as if
anyone in the real world actually cares about it. It was also
weird that "artificial intelligence" is listed as one of the
fringe science ideas in the beginning. Finally, it's so lazy in
the title sequence that the same terms are repeated and it's not
even trying to depict "moving around a space" where the letters
are.

It's also a little lame that in the very first episode we see
Agent Dunham half-naked in bed and then it's a crucial plot point
that she has to disrobe to her underwear for us to gawk at. It's
especially ridiculous because part of the character background is
that she's not respected by people (who constantly call her
"sweetheart") for being a woman and that she is a particularly
strong woman and defender of woman (in her defense of the raped
women in her past). This is so ridiculous, because in one part of
the show we're supposed to be appalled by the bad behavior of the
men vis-a-vis her gender, but in another part the producers put
us right into their seat.
  • TV Shows
  • Fringe

entry.title: Game: Axelay (SNES, 1992)
entry.content:
Game: Axelay (SNES, 1992)20130414
I played through this game in about an hour, using an infinite
lives cheat code. I had the standard complaints about the
invisible bullets and horizontal-ness that I normally have about
old shmups. BUT, the visuals and enemies in this game were so
amazing that it was definitely worth playing through to see them
all. The two kind of levels was a really neat touch that I
enjoyed.

Total time: 0:47
  • Video Games
  • Axelay
  • SNES
  • 1992

entry.title: Game: Contra 3 (SNES, 1992)
entry.content:
Game: Contra 3 (SNES, 1992)20130414
I played this for twenty minutes and got to the middle of the
second side-scrolling stage. There was a lot of neat stuff going
on in the game. I liked the "set piece" moments and I though the
top-down stages were neat.

On one level, this game is a lot like a shmup, so you'd think that
I would like it a lot, but I didn't. I think the reason I didn't
was that the character was very hard to maneuver, so you felt like
it wasn't your fault you were dying. When I finally died, I had to
fight a boss while clinging to the side of a wall and it felt very
unfair, like I couldn't do anything about it.

I'm sure if my first console were a SNES, I would have loved this
game as much as I loved Contra I, but this didn't do it for me.

Total time: 0:19
  • Video Games
  • Contra 3
  • SNES
  • 1992

entry.title: Game: Final Fantasy Mystic Quest (SNES, 1992)
entry.content:
Game: Final Fantasy Mystic Quest (SNES, 1992)20130414
I started this game and played for a little more than two
hours. I got up through the Wintry Cave.

I remember playing this game when I was a kid and thinking it was
really strange, for a Final Fantasy game, but fine. As I got
older, I thought back on it as being silly and I recognized what a
bad reputation it had with a lot of people. There's this idea that
it was released in the US instead of FF5 and that's it is very
simple and bland.

I see where those people are coming from, because it is definitely
a lot simpler than what came directly before or directly after,
but I'm finding it very enjoyable.

Although it was very clearly designed as "My First RPG", the
things that they did to streamline it are fine and even good. In
fact, it anticipates changes in later Final Fantasy games. For
example:

- The overworld is not a map that you can walk around on (and get
lost) [or find secrets], instead it is a graph of interconnected
nodes. This is just like FF10. The lack of random battles to get
in is compensated with the "battleground" concept, which gives
you an indication of how much you should be grinding and gives a
nice little reward.

- When you die in battle, you can immediately try again from
where your stats were before the battle started. This is like
FF13. Unfortunately, whereas FF13 used this to make every
battle very challenging (combined with the no meta-game), in
FF:MQ the battles aren't particularly tough. (Although the
status effects are common and brutal.)

- Weapons and armor are automatically equipped and you always use
what is best. Except not exactly, because you can change weapons
really simply with the shoulder buttons. I like this because in
FF4, for instance, there's basically only three situations where
you would ever want to not use the best stuff. (1) When you go
to the Dark Elf cave, (2) when you fight the elements and want
to use the right protections, and (3) when you can't afford the
best for everyone and want to control who gets it. This
streamlining is very nice.

- You can save /anywhere/!

- All enemies are visible.

Another thing about the game I'm enjoying is the light action
elements. I associate them a lot with Lufia II, although this game
predates it. It adds a nice bit of variety and fun.

I find the story to very bland, but passable. It's very similar to
the straight-forward-ness of FF1 or Zelda, but with a few fun
dialogue choices and elements.

Total time: 2:19
  • Video Games
  • Final Fantasy Mystic Quest
  • SNES
  • 1992

entry.title: Game: Parodius Da! (SNES, 1992)
entry.content:
Game: Parodius Da! (SNES, 1992)20130414
I keep trying to playing Parodius games, because I'm fascinated by
the insane world and visuals, but I just can't stand the
gameplay. I really dislike it when a shmup has a complex power-up
system that makes it so when you die, you're totally defenseless
going forward. Furthermore, I really notice the environmental
dodging mechanics of these Gradius-style games and don't like it.

Total time: 0:10
  • Video Games
  • Parodius Da!
  • SNES
  • 1992

entry.title: Game: Shodai Nekketsu Kōha Kunio-kun (SNES, 1992)
entry.content:
Game: Shodai Nekketsu Kōha Kunio-kun (SNES, 1992)20130414
I played this game for a bit, but I got stuck at the entrance to
the hotel and couldn't get out. I could understand enough of the
Japanese to read the menus and some of the dialogue like "Kunio
went up in level!" but I didn't understand what I was supposed to
do. The game is a lot slower paced in the combat than River City
Ransom, so it wasn't as exciting. I read online that they dropped
the shopping part and it is more like an open-world beat-em up
with RPG-style levels, rather than choives in what you learn,
etc. It doesn't sound as exciting.

Total time: 0:08

  • Shodai Nekketsu Kōha Kunio-kun
  • SNES

entry.title: Game: Super Double Dragon (SNES, 1992)
entry.content:
Game: Super Double Dragon (SNES, 1992)20130414
I played through the first mission of this game. Another bland,
slow-paced beat-em up. The boss battle of the level was so
anti-climatic that I didn't even know it was the boss until the
level ended. I just trapped in a corner and hit him until it was
over. Boring.

entry.title: Game: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles 4: Turtles in Time (SNES, 1992)
entry.content:
Game: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles 4: Turtles in Time (SNES, 1992)20130414
I played through the first level of this game. It's definitely a
lot more enjoyable than the NES games, because it is a lot faster
paced. But still, it is a boring beat-em-up. The boss fight was
the worst, because basically it was "dodge while the boss is where
you can't hit him then pummel him until he goes back."  Nothing
about the combat was interesting.

Total time: 0:06

entry.title: Game: Arcana (SNES, 1992)
entry.content:
Game: Arcana (SNES, 1992)20130413
I played this for a short period of time to get a little bit of a
taste. It felt like it would be very similar to Etrian Odyssey,
although not nearly as tight. The reason I definitely wouldn't
give it any more time is that there was no mapping facility,
insanely "same" looking dungeons, and painful mazes. Life is too
short for that.

Total time: 0:10

  • Arcana
  • SNES
  • 1992

entry.title: Game: Soul Blazer (SNES, 1992) (4)
entry.content:
Game: Soul Blazer (SNES, 1992) (4)20130413
I played today for about three hours and beat the game. I found
the game to continue to be very adorable. The final area wasn't
particularly hard, but it was very fun to get the Phoenix shot
upgrade.

Overall, I found the game to be very fun and cute. I would
definitely recommend it for the good mechanics and the nice
story. The story and mechanics, however, don't feel good enough to
me to warrant many replays, so I don't think I will play it
again. But I definitely will think of it fondly.

I'm excited to see what connections future Quintet games will have
to this world.

Total time: 7:59
  • Video Games
  • Soul Blazer
  • SNES
  • 1992

entry.title: Movie: Robot & Frank, starring Frank Langella (2012)
entry.content:
Movie: Robot & Frank, starring Frank Langella (2012)20130413
My wife and I saw a preview for this a long time ago and thought it
was very cute. It definitely was. The ending was pretty amazing
too. I really liked the robot's dialogue. Something admirable about
the movie is how "simple" the plot is, but it is still very
entertaining.

entry.title: Game: Soul Blazer (SNES, 1992) (2)
entry.content:
Game: Soul Blazer (SNES, 1992) (2)20130411
I played for about two hours today and had a very good time. I
got to the third area and did almost everything I could at this
point in the earlier areas. Although I know that there will be
more to do once I can damage metal enemies.

The game is very cute and there's a lot more connections and
similarities to Actraiser. It's like you're a different avatar of
"The Master". You move around to different towns to restore. There
was even a kid named Teddy! (That's the name of a kid from
Bloodpool in Actraiser.) I really enjoyed the second area, because
it was a town of animals. In both of the first two areas, you also
go into the dreams of a plant :) It was neat too when an old man
says he's was lonely when his wife died but then got a goat to
take care of; when you talk to the goat, it says it's the wife
reincarnated and even though she can't talk to her husband, she's
glad to be around him. Cute.

The combat is getting a little more complex as there are more
enemies that shoot projectiles, etc. But it's not incredibly
complicated, because the controls are so stiff and tile-based.

Total time: 2:39
  • Video Games
  • Soul Blazer
  • SNES
  • 1992

entry.title: Game: Joe & Mac (SNES, 1991)
entry.content:
Game: Joe & Mac (SNES, 1991)20130410
I played this for the first two levels. I remember seeing this
game in Nintendo Power and being incredibly impressed by the
visuals. Now that I am older and playing it, it feels like the
visuals are the main reason for this game being terrible. The
sprites are too big for the action and the hit boxes are real
bad. Amazingly, it is a 2D platformer with camera problems. When
you die, if you move to the right, then the screen doesn't scroll
with your ghost. This made it so I couldn't see the next platform,
I had to go backwards then right again to get it to
scroll. There's really nothing special about this game at all.

Total time: 0:06
  • Video Games
  • Joe & Mac
  • SNES
  • 1991

entry.title: Game: Romancing SaGa (SNES, 1992)
entry.content:
Game: Romancing SaGa (SNES, 1992)20130410
I played this for a bit. Although my Japanese is good enough to
understand all the words on the interface, I couldn't get anything
out of the story. The mechanics of the game are very confusing
(like most Saga games I've played) and not particularly appealing.

The row system is a little neat and there's clearly a lot of
freedom. The ability to see the hordes of monsters on the screen
is interesting. But... I won't play it.

Total time: 0:11
  • Video Games
  • Romancing SaGa
  • SNES
  • 1992

entry.title: Game: Soul Blazer (SNES, 1992)
entry.content:
Game: Soul Blazer (SNES, 1992)20130410
I played this for about forty minutes and had a really good
time. I've played Illusion of Gaia before and it's a lot like
it. It's a traditional action RPG, but there are something neat
things about it.

In the story/structure, it is very similar to Quintet's Actraiser
(which I just played), in that as you fight monsters, you
"restore" lost parts of the towns and unlock people who were
captive and now tell you about their lives. I've enjoyed the
reveals so far. My favorite was a goat that, after giving you a
hint, said, "I have other things to attend to now", and then
walked off.

In the battle mechanics, it's also like Actraiser in that there
are monster spawn points that release one monster after
another. The difference, though, is that here you just have to
kill a certain number and then the spawn point is sealed. Since
you know where they are going to spawn, there's a temptation to
sit on top of it and spam the attack, but they thought of that and
the enemies are invulnerable when they first appear, but they can
still hurt you. Instead, you have to stand a little bit of a way
back and spam the attack button. =) I haven't gotten to a place
where the combat is tricky, but it does feel good, and that counts
for a lot.

I'll definitely keep playing this.

Total time: 0:43
  • Video Games
  • Soul Blazer
  • SNES
  • 1992
